pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:0.5: 26. The training rule on asking for thread
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.2: On one occasion when the monks from the group of six were making robes, they asked for a large amount of thread.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.3: Yet even when their robes had been sewn, there was much thread left over.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.5: “Well, let’s ask for more thread and get weavers to weave us robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.7: Yet even when the robe-cloth had been woven, there was much thread left over.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.8: A second time they asked for more thread and got weavers to weave them robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.9: Once again there was much thread left over.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.10: A third time they asked for more thread and got weavers to weave them robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.12: “How can the Sakyan ascetics ask for thread and then get weavers to weave them robe-cloth?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.13: The monks heard the complaints of those people,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.14: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.15: “How can the monks from the group of six ask for thread and then get weavers to weave them robe-cloth?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.16: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha assembled and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.17: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.20: “… Foolish men, how can you ask for thread and then get weavers to weave you robe-cloth?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.21: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.22: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.23: ‘If a monk himself asks for thread, and then gets weavers to weave him robe-cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.8: there are six kinds of thread:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.9: linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.11: If he gets it woven by weavers, then every effort constitutes wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.12: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.13: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.14: “And, monks, it should be relinquished in this way.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.15: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.16: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth which I got woven by weavers after asking for the thread myself is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.17: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.20: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.21: If he got it woven, and he perceives that he did, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.22: If he got it woven, but he is unsure if he did, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.23: If he got it woven, but he perceives that he did not, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.24: If he did not get it woven, but he perceives that he did, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.25: If he did not get it woven, but he is unsure if he did, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.26: If he did not get it woven, and he perceives that he did not, there is no offense.
